newsitem.title: USA: U.S. HEADLINE STOCKS - Issues to watch - Aug 19.
newsitem.headline: U.S. HEADLINE STOCKS - Issues to watch - Aug 19.

text.p: -- Microsoft Corp said it had received a request for information about the streaming media business from the Department of Justice.

-- Dow Chemical Co's share price slipped in after-hours trading Monday after a jury in a class action lawsuit determined the company had been negligent in testing silicone for human breast implants. The shares extended their drop in overnight trading in London, being quoted 1/2 lower at 88-1/2 after shedding two points in New York on Monday to finish at 90.
-- Some critics argue the proposed tobacco pact needs to raise cigarette prices far more than $0.62 per pack to meet the plan's targets for cutting teenage smoking, the Wall Street Journal reported.
-- The Grand Union supermarket chain may get an emergency loan of up to $75 million, and the lenders may include George Soros's investment firm, the Wall Street Journal reported.
-- Two more big pension funds have filed lawsuits against Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp, the Wall Street Journal reported.
-- Smith Barney is nearing settlement of a sexual discrimination suit filed against it by 26 current and former female employees, the Wall Street Journal reported.
-- Toyota Motor Corp said it aims to nearly double its operating profits in the next few years, the Wall Street Journal reported.
-- Tele-Communications said it launched a tender offer to buy back up to 10 million shares of its Liberty Media Group common stock.
-- Motorola Inc said it filed seven more patent infringment claims against Qualcomm Inc.
-- Several technology stocks firmed overnight in London, led by Digital Equipment Corp, which introduced two new notebook computer models.
